utterances: ...That...
No question.
...That's exactly what it is.
No question.
Absolutely.
...That somebody practices and practices and, you know, develops a certain skill at it, so...
So regulate - yes or no?
Up in the air.
OK, well - OK, there you go.
All right, final question.
Speaking of...
Like a hail Mary pass...
I can't think of a segue.
I can't think of a segue to Playboy.
This week, Playboy executives announced that it's going PG-13.
They're dropping the nudity, but staying racy.
They claim they'll stay sexy.
And the decision was driven by business, apparently.
Playboy is saying that they actually can get more business by not having completely nude women in the magazine, and they can highlight other things.
And I see both of you nodding, like, really, you know, thoughtfully about this, like...
I don't know what you're talking about.
Who wants to - who wants to go first?
I'll take it on first.
Go ahead, Corey.
I mean, look at what's happening with the Sports Illustrated issue.
Every year, it gets more and more racy.
The women are wearing less and less.
And if you see the preview of what's happening in 2016, the woman on the cover's literally going to be wearing - what do you call - dental floss as her...
Bathing suit,"" air quotes.
OK.
Swimsuit issue.
Yes, in air quotes, thank you.
And so that's the competition that Playboy's had to deal with for the past 10 years or more.
And so if that's the competition and what they used to sell is more readily accessible, especially on the Internet, it's a good business decision for them to make this adjustment now.
Can you see yourself, like, just going up and buying it without - you know, just like you'd buy GQ?
I could buy it the same way I buy GQ, the way I buy Maxim.
And Maxim just had a male on the cover for the first time, so the paradigm is shifting in men's magazines in general.
And I think it makes a lot of sense for - this is a very smart business decision for Playboy.
Bridget, what do you think?

I'm wondering is this a victory, in a sense, for modesty, just ceding to - they've got to be thinking of the global market, where there are certain countries where it's just not - just can't, you know, show naked women on a newsstand openly.
I don't know, what do you think about it?
At what point were people alerted about these problems, asked Bertrand.
How were the controls done?
It's clear these implants were substandard, so why didn't we know this earlier?
(SOUNDBITE OF SONG, ""PATTON STATE HOSPITAL"")
Right, although they have a good underground market in those countries (laughter).
But, you know, I think the real Playboy surprise would be if Hef dated a woman over 30.
But, you know, I think that there are so many magazines out there dedicated to, you know, so many elements of pornography.
And, you know, I used to work at Tower Records in college, so they had the full span of them, and everybody shoplifted them.

And - but, you know, if you want to just let the hustlers, you know, do their little seedy trash thing, then, you know, I think that Playboy's been hanging out in this middle area for so long anyways.
So it kind of makes sense for them to just say hey...
Enough.
Arsalan, you've got the final word, like, fast.
You know, people have for decades been joking that I only read Playboy for the articles.
And now they can actually, you know, say that with some truth.
I think it actually speaks to the ubiquitousness of pornography on the Internet.
I mean, I think it shows how irrelevant these magazines have become because of the technological age.
We'll see.
We'll see.
Corey Ealons is a former Obama White House aide and Democratic strategist.
Bridget Johnson is Washington bureau chief for PJ Media and Arsalan Iftikhar is an attorney and commentator.
Thank you all or so much.
Peace.
Thank you.
Thanks, Michel.
Good morning, I'm Steve Inskeep.
A 4th grade teacher in Wichita, Kansas said she'd do something crazy if her kids met a goal.
She challenged her class at Colvin Elementary to complete their homework for 100 straight days.
The Wichita Eagle reports two kids missed their assignments in October, the kids had to start over but then they made the 100 days.
And so, now teacher Brianna Falvey has to pay up.
She committed to show up to class wearing a prom dress and orange hair.
It's MORNING EDITION.
North Korea, meanwhile, experienced another nationwide Internet outage today.
It lasted for about half an hour.
This followed a blackout that went on for some nine hours yesterday and raised a lot of questions about who or what could be behind the disruption.
Dyn Research has been watching the outages.
The firm studies internet performance around the world.
And Doug Madory, Dyn's director of Internet analysis, was among the first people to flag what was happening.
Welcome to the program, Doug.
Hello.
So when did you first notice?
What exactly did you see?
So we monitor - one of our data sources that we use is BGP - that's Border Gateway Protocol.
And what that is is just the information that the Internet service providers around the world exchange with each other on how to direct traffic around the Internet from one place to another.
And so the BGP routes for North Korea starting on Sunday started to become very unstable.
We saw them go down, come right back up, go down, come right back up, and was having a lot of difficulty staying online.
Help us understand in layman's terms, like, what happened.
I don't know how common it is for North Korea to have outages.
Sure.
In the last couple of years, there's been occasions that they have had outages.

And because they are the only party that handles international connectivity for North Korea, when they have an outage then essentially they have a national outage on this very small Internet they have.
So what we saw in the last couple of days was not something that I've observed before.
Typically the outages are brief.
They are also isolated events.
And we don't see this 24 hours of routing instability where they are struggling to maintain a connection followed by nine and a half hours of blackout.
How large is the network of North Korea?
I mean, give us some comparison.
Absolutely.
It's a little over a thousand IP addresses for the country.
As comparison, the Internet - the United States is just under a billion, and so it is quite small.
It's not unusual to see Internet outages in many places in the world, right?
I mean, give us some examples of other instances where governments experience Internet outages.
Why - you know, how does this compare?
OK.
Sure.

There have been a number of cases in the last couple of years, either by the direction of the government - that included Syria, Egypt and then last year was Sudan - and then even in cases of antigovernment protestors or forces in Thailand and Libya.

North Korea, like Cuba and Uzbekistan and a handful of countries that rely on a single ISP for their international connectivity, they have an outage then that means they are shut off from the global Internet.
What do you make of the speculation that the U.S.
is somehow responsible for this outage?
I think this doesn't look like an outage as far as like a fiber cut or a power outage - some of the more catastrophic technological failures that cause Internet outages.
Like I said, we saw these networks struggling to maintain connections for hours and hours until finally they dropped offline.

And so that's more consistent with two possibilities - benign explanation would be that this is just extraordinarily poor timing for a software glitch on the router or this is also consistent with some sort of a denial of service attack directed at the network of North Korea.

Given the sophistication was quite low, it does seem that if it were a cyber-attack that it would be surprising to find out a nation-state did this and it took them hours to take down this tiny network.
Doug Madory - he's the director of Internet analysis for Dyn Research.
He joined us to talk about the Internet blackouts North Korea has been experiencing over the last 24 hours.
Thanks so much for explaining it to us.
Thank you.
Now let's talk about the money the campaigns themselves raise.
All through the Republican primaries, President Obama's campaign raised far more money than Mitt Romney's campaign.
But now the money gap is narrowing, as NPR's Peter Overby reports.
